etymology.description: 之 (possessive/linker) + 意 (meaning; intention) = ‘the meaning/intention of (something)’
etymology.interpretation: Classical-style noun phrase where 之 marks possession or linkage, yielding ‘the meaning/intention of X’. Often follows a noun or clause in formal/literary Chinese to express attribution.

examples.chinese: 我无嘲讽之意(我無嘲諷之意)。
此言并无冒犯之意(此言並無冒犯之意)。
examples.pinyin: Cǐ yán bìng wú màofàn zhī yì.
examples.english: These words carry no intent to offend.

examples.chinese: 他的沉默似有拒绝之意(他的沉默似有拒絕之意)。
examples.pinyin: Tā de chénmò sì yǒu jùjué zhī yì.
examples.english: His silence seems to suggest a refusal.
